Tommy.Action: Tries to reload rifle under intense gunfire despite struggling fingers, perseveres to defend himself and escape.
Struggles to reload his rifle under fire, fingers fumbling and training forgotten.
Despite fumbling, manages to chamber a round by repeatedly thrusting his finger into the rifle breach.
Fires blindly until empty and scrambles away under intense gunfire.
Shouts 'ANGLAIS!' to alert French troops and is allowed through despite their fear and bitterness.
Observes the frightened, dirty faces of the French soldiers without judgment as he passes.
Helps Gibson scoop sand over a dead body, sharing a moment of silent cooperation.
Shares water with Gibson, carefully catching drops and licking them off his palm, showing resourcefulness and a small act of camaraderie.
Moves off when the man at the back of the line is unwelcoming and points at his own insignia, showing tolerance despite rejection.
Wanders among the long lines of soldiers waiting patiently, observing the situation without complaint, indicating patience and acceptance.
Buries his face in the sand during the bombing, a self-protective action without indication of concern for others in this excerpt.
Moves off when confronted by a soldier from a different unit, avoiding conflict or confusion.
Observes the situation carefully, noting the breakwater (The Mole) and hospital ship, showing situational awareness.
Buries his face in the sand during the bombing, a natural protective reaction under attack.
Looks down at several patients on stretchers left behind, notices one still alive, and with Gibson, they grab the stretcher and hustle down the beach towards the mole.
Notices wounded men left behind and immediately helps carry a stretcher towards the evacuation point.
Acts decisively and collaborates with Gibson to move patients despite chaotic conditions.
Pushes forward with the stretcher despite the crowd and narrow mole, showing determination to help.
Leans out over the edge of the mole with a 20ft drop, taking risks to continue moving forward.
Pushes forward with the stretcher through a narrow, crowded mole despite obstacles and the Warrant Officer's disapproval.
Weaves along the mole, carefully navigating a dangerous 20ft drop where the rail is missing, showing physical awareness and caution.
Runs with the stretcher toward the base of the mole upon hearing the ship's whistle, demonstrating promptness and responsiveness.
Fails to catch the ship in time, as indicated by the Warrant Officer's comment that they have missed it.
Breaks through a tight crowd of soldiers and stops in front of a jagged chasm with only a narrow plank across it.
Encourages Gibson to run across the narrow plank together, showing teamwork and support.
Shakes off help from a stretcher bearer, pushing past to continue his task.
Takes a calculated risk by running across a narrow, unstable plank over a dangerous drop, maintaining concentration and recovering from a slip.
Shakes off help from stretcher bearers and pushes past to continue his task, showing determination and confidence.
Reluctantly follows Gibson onto the plank when ordered by the Able Seaman.
Looks over at the thousands queuing on the mole, showing awareness of the situation.
Complies with the Second Lieutenant's wave to move along without question.
Does not question or resist being sent back up the line, showing passivity.
Takes in the overwhelming situation calmly, recognizing 'every man for himself' without panic.
No direct action or statement by Tommy in this excerpt; he is among the soldiers trapped on the mole during the bombing.
Grabs a flailing soldier by the shoulders and yanks him clear from being crushed by the sinking ship.
Grabs a flailing soldier by the shoulders and yanks him clear from being crushed by the sinking ship's hull.
Slips into the water and pulls himself out, then helps push others into the group.
Makes himself inconspicuous amongst the Highlanders, eyes down.
Slips into the water and pulls himself out, then follows others up onto the mole, making himself inconspicuous among the soldiers.
Grabs the shoulder of an exhausted soldier to steady him on the rail as the launch bounces off the destroyer.
Grabs the exhausted soldier's shoulder to steady him on the rail as the launch bounces off the destroyer, attempts to help him climb the cargo nets despite the danger.
Follows orders and moves below decks promptly when urged by sailors and nurses, showing situational awareness and cooperation.
Does not hesitate or panic during the dangerous transfer from launch to destroyer, maintaining composure.
Watches the door to the hold close and looks uneasy, seeking a quick way out in case the ship goes down.
Watches the door to the hold close and looks for a quick way out in case the ship goes down, showing situational awareness and caution.
Eats hungrily and uneasily but does not engage in panic, maintaining composure in a crowded, stressful environment.
Spots Gibson waving in the dark hold and climbs up the steps with Alex as the ship sinks, showing awareness and cooperation.
Spots Gibson waving in the dark hold and climbs up the steps with Alex as the ship sinks, escaping just in time.
Tries to climb into the overloaded rowboat despite being pushed off by the men inside.
Accepts part of the painter rope from Alex and helps quietly drag it behind the boat as it rows to shore.
Attempts to climb into an overloaded rowboat despite being pushed off.
Grabs part of the painter rope and quietly drags it behind the boat to shore, showing awareness and cooperation.
Keeps sucking juice from the tin longer before handing it to Gibson.
Bangs a tin of vegetables on a rock, causing it to leak, then sucks the juice before handing it to Gibson.
Watches the Vanquisher loading troops with a sense of despair, showing passivity in a critical moment.
Gets on his feet promptly and follows Alex and the Highlanders towards a grounded fishing trawler that might be usable when the tide comes in.
No direct actions or statements by Tommy in this excerpt to evaluate competence.
Gets up, climbs to the door, cracks it open, crawls into the well, and peeks over the rail to assess the water level in the boat.
Throws open the door and grabs the seaman, pulling him down into the hold despite Highlander1's confusion.
Jolts awake alertly at the sound of steps outside, moves quickly to the door, and acts decisively by grabbing the seaman and pulling him down into the hold.
Grabs the Seaman and pulls him down into the hold quickly upon confusion, showing decisive action under pressure.
Stares at the bullet hole letting in light without immediate reaction or taking cover, indicating a momentary lapse in situational awareness.
Calms others by explaining the bullet holes are target practice, preventing panic and rash actions.
Recognizes that the bullet holes are target practice and advises others not to react, preventing unnecessary exposure.
Dismisses Alex's accusation that Gibson is a German spy by saying 'Don't be daft.'
Dismisses Alex's accusation that Gibson is a German spy by saying 'Don't be daft.'
Urges Gibson to speak up when Alex is threatening him.
Urges Gibson to speak and reveal information despite language barrier, showing initiative under pressure.
Panics when Gibson does not respond immediately, indicating some loss of composure.
Helps bury Gibson, defends him against accusations, insists they are on the same side, protests when Gibson is forced to risk himself, says 'He saved our lives.'
Refuses to volunteer to get off the ship despite the danger to others.
Helps bury Gibson, showing respect and empathy; argues against sacrificing Gibson, emphasizing fairness and loyalty to comrades.
Refuses to volunteer to get off the ship despite the need, prioritizing self-preservation over group survival.
Refuses to volunteer to sacrifice himself, stating 'Fuck no. I'm going home.'
Helps Gibson when he grabs for the rifle and they both smash against the hull, showing protective behavior.
Expresses doubt that one man's sacrifice will make a difference, showing a realistic but somewhat dismissive attitude.
Refuses to volunteer to sacrifice himself, stating 'Fuck no. I'm going home.'
Acknowledges the moral dilemma but accepts the consequences, saying 'I'll live with it, but it's wrong.'
Expresses doubt about the effectiveness of one man's sacrifice, 'one man's not going to make enough difference-'
Jumps to help Gibson when he grabs for the rifle, showing quick reaction and teamwork.
Comes up for air despite water pouring in from dozens of holes, showing persistence and presence of mind under pressure.
Stuffs the holes in the trawler's hull as best as he can under extreme pressure, repeatedly plugging leaks despite them popping out.
Sees the sinking trawler and immediately dives into the water to swim to safety and the nearby ship.
Swims through dangerous waters, covered in oil, to reach the Keith despite explosions and sinking ships around him.
Dives under water to protect himself from bomb explosions while swimming to the Keith.
Continues swimming toward the Keith despite swimming through oil and seeing the trawler sinking.
Dives under the water for protection during bombing, holds ears to protect from deafening explosions, then surfaces and swims toward the Keith despite oil in the water and men jumping off the ship.
Spots a yacht heading towards them and pulls for it as hard as he can.
Hangs on for dear life while being held by Peter, showing trust and reliance on others.
Whispers 'Take me home' quietly, showing vulnerability and sincerity in his final moments.
Survives the oil slick and is rescued from the water by Peter despite the spreading flames and chaos.
Lies on the deck with eyes closed, whispering 'Take me home,' showing physical and mental exhaustion but no active effort to help himself.
Steps over other men to get to the stairs, then pokes his head out with Alex to see the cliffs.
Asks Peter politely about the cliffs and where they are.
Gets to his feet and moves carefully over other men to the stairs, showing alertness and initiative.
Pokes his head out with Alex to look at the cliffs despite being told to stay below, showing curiosity but potentially risking safety.
Sticks together with Alex, accepts help from the elderly man without complaint.
Falls asleep on the train, showing exhaustion but no interaction with others.
Sticks together with Alex and accepts help calmly, shows endurance by surviving the ordeal.
Flops down and quickly falls asleep on the train, showing exhaustion but also ability to rest when possible.
No active leadership or problem-solving shown in this excerpt; mostly passive and reactive.
Accepts the newspaper from Alex and reads it without complaint.
Does not respond negatively to Alex's despair about public opinion.
Scrambles down into the launch promptly when called by Commander Bolton, showing readiness to follow orders in a tense situation.
Slumps into his seat and passes the newspaper reading duty to Alex, showing some passivity or reluctance to engage with the news.
Reads the newspaper aloud to Alex, sharing the mixed emotions of victory and disaster, engaging with others around him.
Reads the newspaper aloud despite reading poorly, showing effort to understand and engage with the situation.
Quotes from the paper about the military disaster and victory inside deliverance, indicating some awareness of the broader context.
